did.unittitle: Bennet, Harvive Branscomb

scopecontent.p: When Harvie Branscomb (Alabama and Wadham '14) came to Vanderbilt in 1 946 ,it was a small private provincial institution. When he relinquished the Chancellorship in 1963, Vanderbilt was a modern, national university. The day after his election, Harvie wrote to a friend, "Vanderbilt has so far as I can find out,all the problems. It does not have enough money, nor enough room, nor enough buildings.

It has, however, a fine academic tradition." Later, in retrospect, he wrote, "It is clear that I was so convinced that the time had come to establish a great university in the part of the south where I had grown up, that the difficulties in doing it seemed vague and insubstantial in the bright glare of the influences, values and services which would flow from the kind of institution I dreamed of." Once installed as Vanderbilt's fourth Chancellor, Harvie Branscomb never looked back. In the seventeen years of his tenure, Vanderbilt would move into the elite circle of the top 20 universities in the country.

Harvie Branscomb was born in Huntsville, Alabama on Christmas day 1894, the son of Lewis and Nannie Branscomb. His father was a methodist minister. His early memories were dominated by the fixed routine of church life in a community that took for granted the truth of traditional Christianity as it was preached in the churches to which they all belonged. Harvie remembered clearly that his Father's interests were not so much in an evangelistic approach that would try to make saints of people, but in kindling their interests in social problems and political affairs and moral obligations. Harvie recalls that during his college years, he and his father spent many hours discussing critically what he studied and arguing vigorously about intel1ectuial . interests.
Having been graduated from Birmingham College,
Harvie left for Oxford weeks before the start of the First World War.

In the midst of his studies, Harvie and another Rhodes Scholar, Oliver Carmichael, who preceded him as Chancellor of Vanderbilt, volunteered for Herbert Hoover's Committee for Relief in Belgium. They were asked to carry a letter from Cardinal Mercier condemning the German invasion out of occupied Belgium. They were stopped and searched at the border, but with ingenuity and luck they were able to take the document through. For this they were later awarded the Med a i11e d u Ro i Albert, Med a i11e de La Re i ne (Belgium).

It was at Oxford the he became more interested in the personality of the historic Jesus. He became intrigued with the features of Judaism and the teachings of Jesus that had a common bond. He wrote two books, The Teach i ngs of Jesus and his dissertation,Jesus and the Law of Moses. He won the Canon Hall Greek Testament Prize, and was awarded a BA in Theology First Class with the verbal congratulations of the examiners.
With his studies at Oxford complete, Harvie returned to the US, served a brief stint in the Army, and joined the faculty of Southern Methodist University to teach New Testament.

The move to Dallas was important for an special reason. He met and married Margaret Vaughn. Theirs was a charmed meeting of two brilliand minds whose love of humanity, learning and beauty was extraordinary. From this point on, all that Harvie was to be professionally and personally was profoundly shaped by her faithful, delightful, and supportive presence. She died in 1991.

In 1925 at SMU, Harvie demonstrated his fierce support for academic freedom and free expression. It seemed that a young assistant professor, a protege of Harvie Branscomb, was causing a stir in the Methodist hierarchy with his provocative liberal lectures. After the young man was dismissed, Harvie wrote a letter to the local newspaper, disagreeing with the process and its conclusion. No sooner was it published than Harvie was "invited" to leave the institution, in spite of his later appeal to the Board of Trustees. Much later, Harvie wrote, "I hold no honorary degree with more pride than the one conferred on me by SMU some years after these events."

Following his brief stay at SMU, Harvie moved on to Duke, where he spent 21 years, first as a member of the faculty of the School of Religion, then ad Director of the Libraries, and ultimately as dean of the Divinity School.

In 1941 under sposorship of the Carnegie Corporation he published Teachi ng with Books, demonstrating that libraries were seen primarily as repositories for research materials and were little used in class rooms.

He was decorated by the Brazilian government with the Order of the Southern Cross for his work in reorganizing the National Library of Brazil, while serving as chairman of the American Library Association Mission to Brazil in 1 945 .
When in 1946, Harvie Branscomb came to Vanderbilt, he would spend the next seventeen years building the vision he foresaw, and nourishing the academic tradition. Some astonishing things happened.

The University became a more diverse institution as students from all parts of the country were drawn to Vanderbilt, and in 1952 the doors were opened to minority students before the other private universities in the south took this step. Full-time student enrollment increased even as test scores and grades continued to rise.

During Chancellor Branscomb's tenure, the number of full-time faculty had doubled, faculty salaries had almost tripled and more buildings were built than had existed when he arrived. The university's annual budget had increased by more than 400% and the endowment had increased from $38 million in 1946 to $88 million in 1963.

He rebuilt the Medical School and revitalized the Medical Center, which was teetering on the edge of fiscal solvency. Between 1953 and 1963, the schools of Engineering, Divinity and Law acquired their own buildings. Fifteen new residency halls were built. Vanderbilt became a residential campus for undergraduates, which provided the campus culture that remains one of Vanderbilt's greatest strengths.
Harvie reasserted his interest in Brazil, opening up a research center that lives on to this day, and is now the intellectual home to some of Vanderbilt's finest scholars and teachers.

Under his leadership, Vanderbilt was elected to the Association of American Universities, the only member in the South between North Carolina and Texas. An important step was his ability to broaden the base of the Board of Trustees by attracting national figures as well as local leaders. Perhaps most important, was his recruitment of Harold Stirling Vanderbilt to be a part of the University his great-grandfather endowed but never saw. Harold Stirling would become President of the Board and later among the most generous philanthropists in Vanderbilt's history.

During the tumultuous 1 9 6 0 ' s , the James Lawson incident occurred. Lawson was a divinity student who participated vigorously in the civil disobedience of the sit-ins. The question of his expulsion arose. Harvie did not think he should be expelled, and brought the question for decision to the Board of Trustees. He counted on his leadership to persuade the Board not to expell Lawson. The Board did expell him. Later Harvie said he should have acted on the question himself. This experience chagrined him for the rest of his tenure.

Harvie found time to serve his country and higher education nationally. President Truman appointed him the first chairman of the US Advisory Commission for Education Exchange, which he led for four years. He later was named chairman of the Commission on Education and International Affairs of the American Council of Education. He advised the World Bank, the United Nations and other government agencies.

Harvie Branscomb's biography is a history of education in the 20th century, of its continued growth and lustre. Through his efforts and the fullfilment of his visions, Vanderbilt is no longer content with simply being good - it strives for greatness in everything it does.
Long after his retirement, Harvie Branscomb's presence in Nashville signified leadership and action.

People in all walks of life continued to seek his advice and social contact. He entertained and went out to social events right up to the time of his quiet peaceful death. About three months into his 104th year, he complained quite seriousle that he was having a harder time remembering names !

Chancellor Branscomb is survived by three sons, Harvie Branscomb, Jran attorney in Corpus Christi , Texas, Doctor Ben Branscomb, distinguished professor of medicine, at the University of Alabama Medical School, Birmingham, Alabama, and Lewis H. Branscomb, emeritus professor of public policy and corporate management at Harvard University and a member of Vanderbilt's Board of Trustees. He is also survived by nine grandchi1dren and nine great-grandchi1dren.

This strong, determined, scholar, theologian and educator will be sorely missed by his many colleagues world wide and by the numerous people upon whom he has left his rich mark of friendship and wisdom.
F .Tremai ne Bi11ings
(Pennsylvania and Balli o1 '33)

note.p: The correspondence is listed alphabetically. The figure in parentheses immediately following each name indicates the total number of letters from that correspondent in the collection. The full name of the person is given whenever possible. The folder number is listed at the end of each entry preceded by the letter F.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Outgoing. Feb. 7, 1929 - Oct. 31, 1978. Outgoing correspondence arranged chronologically by year, month and day. Letters are holograph, typescript, printed, photocopies and carbon copies. Includes memoranda. There are 4 undated letters. See Outgoing Correspondence Index.

Correspondence - Incoming (Miscellaneous). 6 holograph and typescript letters pertaining to various subjects. (All other incoming correspondence is filed according to appropriate subject, but listed alphabetically by author. See Incoming Correspondence Index).
Academy for Educational Development. Correspondence.

Reports and agendas: Advisory Committee on the Consortium of Universities of the Washington Metropolitan Area, July 17, 1968; Coordinating Council for Higher Education, Resolution; Detroit Institute of Technology-Today, Tomorrow, and in the Generation Ahead; Educational Trends in Certain Professional Schools in the State of Pennsylvania; Innovations in Undergraduate Education; Major Issues to be Faced in Planning the Future of Higher Education; Faculty Development at Tuskegee Institute; A New Approach to Undergraduate Education; Program of Study of the International University for Independent Study; Proposed Establishment of the International University for Independent Study; A Proposed Program for Undergraduate Instruction; Recommendations; Summary of Staff Findings and Recommendations regarding the Structure and Governance of Higher Education; University of Redlands report. Newspaper clippings.
American Association of Colleges Conference on the Humanities. Correspondence.
American Committee to Preserve Abu Simbel. Correspondence, lists of committee.members.
American Council on Education. Reports: Commission on Education and International Affairs; Conference on the Cultural Relations of the United States and the Soviet Union.

Belgian-American Educational Foundation. Correspondence. American Association of C.R.B. Alumni, Inc.: Press release, amended complaint. Historical summary. Lists of members and directors. President's report on lawsuit brought by George Wickes and S. Sheldon Judson, Jr. Newspaper clippings.
Colonial Williamsburg. Correspondence. Printed raaterials-brochure, broadsides, map. Board of Trust minutes, lists of trustees and directors.
Commission on the Humanities of the ACLS. List of participants in the Worcester Conference. Reports: The Graduate School Today and Tomorrow. The Place of Teaching in the Humanities.
Cordell Hull Foundation for International Education. Correspondence. Ballot, contract proposal, and financial statements.

Education and World Affairs. Correspondence. Reports: Report on Mission to India, March 12-28, 1965. Report on Summer Institute Follow-Up Program. Trip itinerary, holograph notes. "International Education Act of 1966" bill.

Foundation for Better Government for Tennessee. Correspondence. Reports: Board of Trust meeting, resolution. Summary of proposals to amend the Constitution of Tennessee. Lists of members of committee.
Hall of Fame for Great Americans. Correspondence. Lists of members, agenda, resolution, rules, minutes of board meeting.
Heald. Hobson and Associates, Incorporated. Correspondence. Agendas, lists of advisors.
Hockaday School. Correspondence. Lists of board members.
Motorola Executive Institute. Correspondence. Reports, list of library books, clippings and holograph notes.

Tusculum College. Correspondence. Lists of board members. Reports: The Academic Scene at Tusculum. Report of the Governance Committee on the Future of Academic Programs at Tusculum College Statement of Purpose, 1977.

UNESCO, 1963-64. Correspondence. Reports, agendas, lists, notes and printed materials: Printed messages from the President of the United States; membership rosters, papers on Freedom of Expression in the Arts; Report on U.S. National Commission, Financial and Staff Resources; Texts of Human Rights Conventions on Slavery, Forced Labor, Political Rights of Women and Genocide; UNESCO and Education; "Report on UNESCO" by Harvie Branscomb published in Bulletin on International Education; "Progress Report on UNESCO" published in Saturday Review; Report of the U.S. Delegation to the 13th General Conference of UNESCO; Report to the Carnegie Corporation on "The Universities of South and East Africa"; Bangkok Conference of Asian National Commissions; holograph notes; trip itineraries; travel notes on a visit to Asia.

UNESCO, 1964-65. Correspondence. Reports: Some problems related to what extent we emphasize foreign students coming here or sending teachers abroad; Some suggestions for a United States position on the problem of the free flow of information; UNESCO after 20 Years; Reports of the U.S. Delegation; Recommendations for the UNESCO program; membership lists.

UNESCO, Minutes and Actions. Reports: Soviet Cultural Influence in North Korea; Objectives; Executive Committee reports on Privileges and Immunities Requirement Bars UNESCO-sponsored Meetings in U.S.,and UNESCO and American Universities - Follow-Up Program.
U.S. Advisory Commission. Correspondence. Remarks at Seventh Annual Birthday of the Americas Dinner; Trip itineraries; Report on European Trip, Summer 1949.
U.S. Public Health Council. Correspondence. Reports, agendas, lists and resolutions.
Urban League and Race Issues. Correspondence. Minutes, lists of board members, by-laws, printed materials.
Vanderbilt University. Board of Trust Committee on the Succession to the Chancellorship. Correspondence.
Vanderbilt University. Documents and Assorted Papers. Correspondence. Papers, reports, agendas and printed materials.

Vanderbilt University. Lawson Affair. Correspondence. Printed articles: "Is Civil Disobedience the Way?" by Harvie Branscomb, "A Policy the University Can Defend" by Robert McGaw, "Vanderbilt's Time of Testing" by J. Robert Nelson, "The Lawson- Vanderbilt Affair, Letters to Dean Nelson," Statement; of Principles and Procedures to be followed in Cases of Student Discipline wherein Issues of Academic Freedom are Raised.

Reports: Statement made by Harvie Branscomb at the Arts and Science Faculty Meeting on March 8, 1960; Statement made by Dr. Quillian to the Student Body at Assembly on Jan. 3, 1961; Recommendations of the Beach Committee appointed to recommend procedures to be followed in the future; Proposed White Paper on "The Lawson-Nelson Case at Vanderbilt University"; "Some Comments and Reflections on the Lawson Episide." Newspaper clippings.
Vanderbilt University. Statue of Harold S. Vanderbilt. Correspondence. Papers and printed materials. Photograph.
World Bank Project. Correspondence. Reports.

World Health Organization. Correspondence. Reports: Committee on International Health to the National Advisory Health Council; Committee on Progranme and Budget, Provisional Minutes of the Fifteenth Meeting; Draft Sixth Report of the Committee on Programme and Budget; Extension of WHO Activities-Research; Health Aspects of World Population; Some Questions and Comments Concerning the Program of the WHO More Particularly in the Field of Education and Training. Holograph notes, lists of members, travel authorizations.
Draft of Board of Trust memorial resolution honoring Gertrude Conaway Vanderbilt, 1978.
Board of Trust memorial resolution honoring William Oscar Jenkins. Remarks made at memorial service for Charles Robinson.
